The IRS is open—fast-track your refund
**********
Sign in
 
The IRS is open—fast-track your refund
**********
Sign in
 
Your W-2 is being delivered
IRS is accepting returns
Claim your refund today!
The IRS is now accepting returns. File now and put money in your pocket as soon 
as today.
 
**********
Get your max refund
The IRS reported an impact to certain filers' refunds till March 3rd. 
Learn more >
 
Get your refund faster, 
guaranteed
¹
Get your refund 5 days before 
IRS delivery in your chosen 
bank account.²
 
5 days before IRS delivery to your bank account for a fee. Terms apply.
Get fast money
 
Track your refund
Once you file, we’ll tell you when to expect your refund and alert you when it lands in your 
bank account.
 
Start filing now
 
 
 
We're looking out for you
 
We’ll never ask for personal information in an email. When you click on a link, the address should always contain 
“intuit.com/”
. 
*Average Refund Amount: Sum of $3,207 is the average refund American taxpayers received based upon IRS data date ending 2/16/24 and may not reflect actual refund amount received. 
You may be able to receive your federal refund early through your bank, credit union or other financial institution. Terms, fees, and delivery dates may vary. Check with your financial institution for details. 
Money movement services are provided by Intuit Payments Inc., licensed as a Money Transmitter by the New York State Department of Financial Services. For more information about Intuit Payments' money transmission licenses, please visit 
https://www.intuit.com/legal/licenses/payment-licenses/
. 
1 If your federal refund is deposited into your selected bank account less than 5 days before the IRS refund settlement date (the date it would have arrived if sent from the IRS directly), then you will not pay the 5 Days Early fee. See 
Terms of Service
 for more details. 
2 5 Days Early to Your Bank Account: Personal taxes only. Your federal tax refund will be deposited to your selected bank account 5 days before the refund settlement date provided by the IRS (the date your refund would have arrived if sent from the IRS directly). The receipt of your refund 5 Days Early is subject to IRS submitting refund information to us at least 5 days before the refund settlement date. IRS does not always provide refund settlement information 5 days early. You will not be eligible to receive your refund 5 Days Early if (1) you take a Refund Advance loan, (2) IRS delays payment of your refund, or (3) your bank’s policies do not allow for same-day payment processing. 5 Days Early fee will be deducted directly from your refund prior to being deposited to your bank account. If your refund cannot be delivered 5 Days Early, you will not be charged the 5 Days Early fee. 5 Days Early program may change or be discontinued at any time.

 to see TurboTax product guarantees, disclaimers and other important information.

We're looking out for you
 
We’ll never ask for personal information in an email. When you click on a link, the address should always contain 
“intuit.com/”
. 
*Offer applies to the cost of TurboTax Full Service (“Full Service”) for 
2024
 personal taxes filed in calendar year 2025 and no other services. To be eligible to participate in the Beat the Price Program (“Program”), customer must: (i) Have used a Certified Public Accountant or other licensed tax preparer to prepare, sign and file their 
2023
 personal tax return (including through Full Service and TurboTax Verified Pros but excluding TurboTax Full Service Business); (2) Sign-up for or sign-into TurboTax Full Service and lock in their discount by 
March 18, 2025;
 and (3) File 2024 personal taxes with Full Service by 
March 25, 2025, 11:59 PM ET.
 Program is available only to legal US residents.
Price will be calculated at the time of 
2024
 tax return filing based on customer’s actual 2023 tax return prep fees minus 10%, or TurboTax’s current forms-based pricing, whichever is lowest, as determined by Sponsor in its sole discretion. The price difference will be adjusted at time of tax filing unless Sponsor requests proof of last year’s payment.
To receive this offer, customer must provide an eligible receipt for 2023 personal taxes (“Eligible Receipt”) upon TurboTax’s request. The Eligible Receipt must be a valid receipt as determined by TurboTax in its sole discretion. If customer does not provide an Eligible Receipt, customer will not be entitled to any discount or an alternative Full Service offer. Price includes 1 federal filing and applicable state filings via Full Service; other products or services are not included. Excludes TurboTax Full Service Business, TurboTax Verified Pro and TurboTax Canada services. Offer not available in combination with any other TurboTax offers and not valid for use with TurboTax self-preparation offerings. TurboTax reserves the right to modify or terminate this offer at any time for any reason in its sole discretion.

subject: Special delivery: Your quarterly update on employee benefits is here
body:
Brush up on tips and best practices to help make the most of open enrollment — and boost utilization 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Benefits enrollment solutions
Here’s your Guardian Group Benefits Client Quarterly
It’s open enrollment season — here’s why enrollment matters.
According to Guardian’s Annual Workplace Benefits Study, 65% of employers feel very strongly that their benefit communications and enrollment process help workers make the best benefit decisions.
1
 
The issue? Only 39% of employees feel the same way, and need more help understanding their benefits.
1
This may signal the need for a different approach to benefit communications. 
Key resources to help empower you (and your employees) this enrollment season
Send 
5 things to check before making your annual benefits enrollment selection
 to your employees to help get them prepared for benefit elections
 
Post 
digital banners
 on your benefits site or in your benefit communications
 
Post our 
Simply Put video series
 (about life, disability, dental, critical illness, and hospital indemnity) on your benefit page or in other benefit communications
 
Share our 
life, oral health, and supplemental health quizzes
 to help engage and educate employees on these benefits
 
Review our 
life
, 
oral health
, and 
supplemental health
 education pages
 
Explore our 
deciding moments
 enrollment page that provides guidance and considerations based on life stage
If you submit enrollment data via EDI, 
download our Open Enrollment EDI FAQ
 for insights and tips for submitting the file.
 
What benefit communications challenges should employers like you consider?
 
With 63% of employers reporting that attracting and retaining talent is the biggest challenge they’ll face next year, overcoming challenges to 
benefits education and utilization will be crucial
.
2 
Here’s what employees are saying about their current experience:    
36% report spending no time researching benefit options
2
 
Only 22% feel extremely confident about their recent benefit selections
3
Why does having a benefit enrollment strategy matter?
Employees are
 
3x more confident
 with their benefit selections when they’re satisfied with enrollment.
4
 Additionally, workers who report satisfaction with their enrollment experience are 
2x more likely to stay at their company
 because of the benefits offered.
4
 
Looking for ways to help grab your employees' attention and increase engagement during enrollment? Consider leveraging these best practices:
Know your audience (what’s important to them, how they prefer to receive benefit information, etc.)
 
Establish a strategy with goals and act on employee feedback
 
Communicate benefits year-round
 
Test tools that engage and educate employees
 
Leverage brokers and carriers for support
Watch 
The Keys to Success: Best practices for benefits engagement
 for practical tips to leverage.
 
Benefit communications across five generations can be challenging, especially for employees who are early in their career. Our enrollment specialists debunk common misconceptions younger employees may have. 
 
Making the Right Connections: Helping younger employees make the right benefits choices
 is packed with examples and insights to help engage employees across generations.
When preparing your upcoming benefit communications, consider these best practices: 
Define your benefits enrollment goal to help take a measured approach
 
Start the discussion with stakeholders as early as possible
 
Understand the needs of your employee base and solicit their feedback
 
Involve leadership to gain support and show your commitment to helping employees understand and get the most out of their benefits
Watch 
Enrollment Case Studies: An inside look at how to optimize your enrollment strategy
 for more ideas and best practices. 
Guardian can help
 
Remember, we’re here to help you. Contact your Guardian representative for assistance on leveraging our 
available tools
 to help support your benefit communication and enrollment needs.
P.S. As you begin your 2025 planning process, review our 
latest report
 on digital benefit trends revolution, for things to consider for your technology planning.
 
1
“
The Keys to Success: Best practices for driving benefits engagement
,” aired 7/10/24.
2

th
 Annual Guardian Workplace Benefits Study, 2024. The Guardian 13th Annual Workplace Benefits Study was fielded in January and February of 2024 and consisted of two online surveys: one among benefits decision-makers (employers) and another among working Americans (employees), allowing us to explore benefits issues from both perspectives. 
3

subject: How employers can help employees overcome the tobacco habit
body:
Tobacco usage and its impact on workforce well-being 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Read our report
Our latest study shows that while tobacco use is declining in the US, almost a third of working Americans use tobacco products. The good news? Workers want help quitting. In fact, 66% of them would be very interested in using a tobacco cessation program through their dental insurance plan if it came at no additional cost. This is especially true for workers whose children may also use tobacco products, especially e-cigarettes. Organizations would benefit, too, by retaining a healthier, more productive workforce and lower medical claims costs.
 
A few of the findings: 
60% of smokeless tobacco users say that if they knew the products harmed their oral health, they would consider quitting.
 
82% of workers with a child who uses tobacco would be interested in a tobacco cessation program if the program were available to dependents.
 
Cigarette smokers take an average of over 7 more days of sick leave per year compared to non-smokers.
Expanding benefits programs to include support for tobacco cessation can be important for oral, physical, and mental health. 
Download the report
 
to discover how to find the right solutions. 
 
 
Explore Guardian Edge
 
Get the latest workplace benefits insights with a variety of content — including articles, checklists, reports, and more — to help support all stages of your employees' journeys. 
Visit Guardian Edge
.
 
Unless otherwise noted, all data is sourced from Guardian’s 13th Annual Workplace Benefits Study, 2024.
 
For broker/agent use only.

subject: How do key life moments affect your employees’ well-being?
body:
Read our latest report to find out 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Read our report
Our latest report shows that working Americans’ well-being is lower than in past years. Contributing to this decline is a lack of control workers feel about the economy. In fact, 
money is the top source of stress in employees’ lives
, with half concerned their retirement savings won’t last as long as they need it to.    
 
The new research also reveals that this sense of uncertainty can be magnified during major life moments — such as having a child, confronting a serious health diagnosis, or becoming a caregiver. As an employer, you have the chance to better support employees during these critical times. Find out which benefits and well-being initiatives can help you support your employees.

subject: Helping employees quit tobacco use
body:
People who smoke have a 10x higher risk for oral cancer compared to nonsmokers 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
The use of tobacco in products like cigarettes, e-cigarettes, and chewing tobacco is linked to problems with oral — and overall — health. People who smoke have a 10x higher risk for oral cancer compared to nonsmokers,
1
 and at least 28 cancer-causing chemicals have been found in smokeless tobacco products.
2
 Not only can these conditions lead to workforce health problems and associated higher claims costs, tobacco use is linked to lower confidence and work performance.
3

subject: Open now to explore how you can help support your employees and their loved ones
body:
You don't often get email from guardian_employee_benefits@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
Because an event, accident, or illness may take any employee away from work 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Group Disability Insurance
Here’s your Guardian Group Benefits Client Quarterly
May is Disability Insurance Awareness Month.
As an HR professional, you likely know the important role that 
disability insurance
 plays in helping provide financial protection to employees if an illness, accident, or other event like maternity keeps them out of work. But many employees may not make this connection, and fail to protect their income the way they protect other things that are innately important to them — health, home, and family.
By shedding light on some of the misconceptions around disability insurance, workers are able to help better protect themselves and employers are able to help better protect their workforces. Use these resources to understand how to help your employees protect their finances, and the role disability insurance plays in their overall well-being:
Download the disability insurance facts and figures report
 
Download the group disability insurance overview flyer
Resources to share with employees:
 
Share the 4 myths about disability insurance article
 
Share the short-term disability insurance Simply Put video
 
Share the long-term disability insurance Simply Put video
 
Employees may underestimate their chances of experiencing an income-disrupting event
 
While 92% of employees are concerned about being financially prepared if one of their household's primary wage earners should become unable to work due to an illness or injury, most people still tend to adopt a “not me” mindset and underestimate their need for disability benefits.
1
Here’s why that mindset can raise concerns
People of all ages, demographics, and professions have roughly the same potential to experience an income-disrupting injury, illness, or condition. In fact, 
25% of today’s 20-year-olds
 will take a disability-related leave before reaching retirement age.
2
 And 30% of US households have had a main wage earner experience at least one injury, illness, or condition that resulted in either a short-term disability (STD) or long-term disability (LTD) leave sometime in the past 10 years.
3
Leading causes of disability claims:
Disability insurance covers a lot more than your employees might realize. Here are the leading causes of disability claims:
4
STD
Maternity
Musculoskeletal (non-back)
Injury (non-back)
Mental and nervous conditions
LTD
Cancer
Musculoskeletal (non-back)
Circulatory
Back
How employers can help:
 
Disability insurance offered through work can play a significant role in helping provide access to financial protection against loss of income due to a disability. On average, 38% of employers pay the full cost of their disability benefit plans, 47% share the cost with workers, and 17% offer employee-pay-all or voluntary disability coverage.
5
Other support for employees facing a possible disability leave
Taking a disability leave may be stressful for employees. These mental wellness resources can help them better manage any challenges they may face:
Discover workplace mental wellness resources and insights
 
Read the employer guide to recognizing and preventing employee burnout
 
Share the Take a Breath exercise video
 
Share this article with 5 helpful stress management techniques
Webinar replay — in case you missed it:
 
Our “A smooth transition: supporting mental health during and after a disability leave” webinar includes an overview with tips on supporting the mental health of employees before, during, and after a disability leave — so they have the resources to take on whatever they’re facing. 
Watch now
 
1,2,3,4,5 
Insuring Your Income: The role of disability insurance in financial wellness
, Guardian 12th Annual Workplace Benefits Study, 2023.

subject: US workers are struggling financially. Can your benefits do more to help?
body:
Start by getting the latest research 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
 
Facing Financial Fragility:
How changes to the economic landscape are impacting Americans’ wallets and habits
Did you know:
 self-reported financial wellness is at its lowest in the last 8 years?
1
 
And that 
our latest report finds
 that finances impact overall well-being more than physical or emotional health? 
US workers are struggling with their financial health due to a complex tapestry of societal and economic challenges. That’s why 80% of employers say it’s “extremely important” to improve the financial security of their employees and their families.  
 
Get the latest insights
 to increase your awareness of the financial challenges that may be weighing your workforce down and what you can do to help.    
 
Get the latest workplace benefits insights, plus a variety of content to help support the well-being of your employees— at work and in life. Explore 
Guardian Edge
.

, FRED Economic Data, 2023

subject: The 2023 Guardian Annual: A whole different perspective
body:
You don't often get email from guardian_employee_benefits@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
In The Guardian Annual, you will see how our investments and innovations impact our customers at critical moments in their lives 
View this email as a web page 
here
I’m proud to share 
The 2023 Guardian Annual
, which focuses on how we work hard to 
inspire well-being
®
 in everything we do and with every decision we make.  
 
Guardian’s proprietary research
1
 shows less than half of employees say their benefits meet all of their needs. So, we have worked to further enrich the lives of our members by expanding our products and services to include mental wellness benefits, a new dental plan for children under 12, and more robust benefits features for those embarking on family planning. And we know that new parents don’t need to deal with the stress of reduced income. We offer the option to waive the typical waiting period on maternity claims and provide access to disability benefits from day one.
 
In 
The Guardian Annual
, you will see how our investments and innovations impact our customers at critical moments in their lives. You will also find stories of people whose lives have been improved through Guardian and who demonstrate how our approach to providing benefits inspire well-being.   
 
One of those profiles is of Dr. Jian Lee at Cumberland Valley Pediatric Dentistry. A Guardian network provider, Dr. Lee shares  our commitment to helping children establish good oral health habits at an early age because of the long-term well-being benefits. That’s why Guardian’s Early Smiles plan covers 100% of dental care for children 12 years and under, helping parents remove a financial barrier to care, encouraging kids’ overall well-being, and building a life-long patient-doctor rapport.
2
 
Thank you for continuing to place your trust in us.
 
Sincerely,
Michael Prestileo
Chief Commercial Officer
The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America
 
guardianlife.com
1
Guardian’s 12th Annual Workplace Benefits Study, 2023
 
2
